subsc: Agricultural extension and research,Central government administration,Animal production

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, project outcome is rated
            unsatisfactory (marginally satisfactory given the situation
            of agricultural services in the country at the start of the
            project and the technical achievements). Project
            sustainability is rated unlikely in the long term. both
            World Bank and Borrower performances were assessed as
            unsatisfactory because project objectives were overly
            ambitious, disbursement conditions for research delayed
            component start-up, no guidelines for participatory on-farm
            research were provided, economic analysis was rudimentary,
            project management was not intensely supervised, the
            Borrower did not provide timely counterpart funds,
            correction actions were too slow in addressing project fund
            mismanagement. Lessons learned included the following:
            Farmer training should also involve functional literacy
            programs and the training of village specialists in critical
            areas of equipment maintenance. In situations where input
            and output markets are weak or non-existent, agricultural
            services cannot limit themselves to generating and diffusing
            technologies--they must either directly or indirectly assist
            producers to develop strong organizations at the local and
            higher levels that can address these issues. To extend the
            reach of extension agents and to improve cost-effectiveness
            and sustainability of interventions, the use of
            para-professionals is an ideal tool. In general, training,
            technology generation, and transfer systems should be set up
            nationwide on a demand-driven basis.
